facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 364 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 364 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 22, 1956, of the former Bombay High Court in I.T.R. No. 31/1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 22, 1956, of the former Bombay High Court in I.T.R. No. 31/1955. A. Palkhivala and IN. Shroff, for the Appellants.

facts.text: The appellants held 570 out of a total issue of 800 shares of the Navjivan Mills Ltd., Kalol, a public limited company.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants held 570 out of a total issue of 800 shares of the Navjivan Mills Ltd., Kalol, a public limited companypany- hereinafter referred to as the Mills.

facts.text: Between the years 1943-47, the Mills purchased 5,000 shares of the Bank of India Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Between the years 1943-47, the Mills purchased 5,000 shares of the Bank of India Ltd. At an extraordinary general meeting of the shareholders of the Bank of India held on May 6, 1948, a resolution was passed

facts.text: At an extraordinary general meeting of the shareholders of the Bank of India held on May 6, 1948, a resolution was passed increasing the share capital of the Bank and offering new shares to existing shareholders in the proportion of one new share for every three shares held.

anchor.surface_text: At an extraordinary general meeting of the shareholders of the Bank of India held on May 6, 1948, a resolution was passed increasing the share capital of the Bank and for that purpose offering new shares to the existing shareholders in the proportion of one new share for every three shares held by the shareholders.

facts.text: The face value of the new shares was Rs. 50, issued at a premium of Rs. 50, so shareholders had to pay Rs. 100 for each new share.

anchor.surface_text: The face value of the new shares was to be Rs. 50, but the shares were issued at a premium of Rs. 50. The shareholders had to pay Rs. 100 for each new share.

facts.text: The Mills as holder of 5,000 shares became entitled to receive 1,6662 shares of the Bank of India at Rs. 100 per share.

anchor.surface_text: The Mills as the holder of 5,000 shares became entitled to receive 1,6662 shares of the Bank of India at the rate of Rs. 100 per share.

facts.text: Bank of India communicated its resolution by letter dated May 25, 1948 and enclosed forms A for acceptance, B for renunciation, and C for allotment to nominees.

anchor.surface_text: The Bank of India companypunicated its resolution by letter dated May 25, 1948 and enclosed therewith three forms, form A for acceptance, form B for renunciation and form C which may companypendiously be called a form for allotment to numberinees.

facts.text: Directors of the Mills passed a resolution to invest in only 66 shares and distribute the right to the remaining 1,600 shares amongst its shareholders in proportion of two shares of Bank per one ordinary share in Mills.

anchor.surface_text: On receiving the circular letter, the Directors of the Mills passed the following resolution Resolved that the companypany having a holding of 5,000 ordinary shares in the capital of the Bank of India Ltd. having number received an intimation from the said Bank that this companypany is entitled to get 1,6662 more ordinary shares on payment of Rs. 50 as capital and Rs. 50 as premium per each share and it is companysidered proper to invest in the said issue of the said Bank the funds of this companypany to the extent of 66 shares only and to distribute the right of this companypany to the remaining 1,600 shares of the said issue amongst the shareholders of this companypany in the proportion of the shares held by them in this companypany.

facts.text: The Mills exercised the right to take over only 66 shares out of the shares offered and resolved that the right to the remaining 1,600 shares be distributed amongst its 800 shareholders.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, the Mills exercised the right to take over only 66 shares out of the shares offered and resolved that the right to the remaining 1,600 shares be distributed amongst its 800 share holders.

facts.text: The seven appellants as holders of 570 shares of the Mills became entitled to 1,140 shares of the Bank of India.

anchor.surface_text: The seven appellants as holders of 570 shares of the Mills became entitled to 1,140 shares of the Bank of India.

facts.text: The appellants agreed to the allotment of these shares and ultimately transferred them to Jesinghbai Investment Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants agreed to the allotment of these shares and ultimately transferred them to a private companypany--Jesinghbai Investment Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Assessment of the seven appellants was reopened under s. 34(1)(a) of the Indian Income Tax Act by the Income Tax Officer treating the release by the Mills of the shares as distribution of dividend, value taxable under s.12.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment of the seven appellants and of other shareholders of the Mills was reopened under s. 34 1  a  of the Indian Income Tax Act by the Income Tax Officer on the footing that, the release by the Mills of the shares of the Bank of India amounted to a distribution of dividend and the value of the right released in favour of the shareholders though taxable under s. 12 of the Act, had escaped tax.

facts.text: Order of Income Tax Officer reassessing income of seven appellants confirmed by Appellate Assistant Commissioner and Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Income Tax Officer reassessing the income of the seven appellants was companyfirmed in appeal by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and by the Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court at Bombay under s.66(1): Whether distribution of right to apply for shares of Bank of India by Navjivan Mills in favour of assessees amounted to distribution of dividend within s.2(6A).

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the appellants, the i following question was submitted by the Tribunal to the High Court at Bombay under s. 66 1  of the Income Tax Act Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the distribution of the right to apply for the shares of the Bank of India by Navjivan Mills Ltd. in favour of the assessees amounted to a distribution of dividend within the meaning of s. 2 6A  of the Indian Income Tax Act.

facts.text: High Court reframed the question slightly and answered in the affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court reframed the question as follows Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case, the distribution of the right to apply for the shares of the Bank of India by Navjivan Mills Ltd., in favour of the assessees amounted to a distribution of dividend? and answered it in the affirmative.

facts.text: High Court observed that even if not within extended meaning of s.2(6A), it was dividend in ordinary meaning.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court observed that the definition of dividend in s. 2 6A  was an inclusive and number an exhaustive definition, and even if the distribution of the right to the shares of the Bank of India companyld number be regarded as dividend within the extended meaning of that expression in s. 2 6A , it was still dividend within the ordinary meaning of that expression and was taxable as income in the hands of the appellants.

facts.text: When shares offered by Bank of India, the right to apply had market value of Rs. 100 per share.

anchor.surface_text: It is undisputed that when the shares were offered by the Bank of India to its shareholders, the right to apply for the shares had a market value of Rs. 100 per share.

facts.text: New shares quoted in market at more than Rs. 200, difference between payable Rs.100 and market quotation is value of the right.

anchor.surface_text: The face value of the new share was Rs. 50 but the shareholders had to pay a premium of Rs. 50, thus making a total payment of Rs. 100 for acquiring the new share. The new shares were quoted in the market at more than Rs. 200 and the difference between the amount payable for acquiring the shares under the right offered by the Bank of India and the market quotation of the shares was indisputably the value of the right.

facts.text: The Mills requested Bank of India to allot shares to its nominees, amounting to transfer of the right.

anchor.surface_text: The Mills requested the Bank of India to allot the shares to its numberinees, and the request for allotment to its numberinees amounted to transfer of the right.

facts.text: By resolution, Mills transferred right of value Rs. 200 for each share held by its shareholders.

anchor.surface_text: By its resolution, the Mills in truth transferred a right of the value of Rs. 200 for each share held by its shareholders.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that the distribution amounted to distribution of dividend.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the view that the High Court was right in holding that the distribution of the right to apply for and obtain two shares of the Bank of India  at half their market value  for each share held by the shareholders of the Mills amounted to distribution of dividend.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on November 22, 1960 by SHAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. November 22. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SHAH, J.-This is an appeal by seven appellants with leave granted by the High Court of Judicature at Bombay certifying that it involves a question of importance.

facts.text: Appeal by seven appellants with leave granted by Bombay High Court certifying question of importance.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by seven appellants with leave granted by the High Court of Judicature at Bombay certifying that it involves a question of importance. The appellants held 570 out of a total issue of 800 shares of the Navjivan Mills Ltd., Kalol, a public limited companypany- hereinafter referred to as the Mills.

the definition in s. 2 6A  of the Income Tax Act, in enlarging the scope of the question and in answering it in the light of its ordinary meaning. There is no substance in this contention.

Dividend is defined in s. 2 6A  as inclusive of various items and exclusive of certain others which it is not necessary to set out for the purpose of this appeal. Dividend in its ordinary meaning is a distributive share of the profits or income of a company given to its shareholders.

Dividend in its ordinary meaning is a distributive share of the profits or income of a company given to its shareholders. When the Legislature by s. 2 6A  sought to define the expression dividend it added to the normal meaning of the expression several other categories of receipts which may not otherwise be included therein.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances of the case the distribution of the right to apply for the shares of the Bank of India by Navjivan Mills Ltd. in favour of the assessees amounted to a distribution of dividend within the meaning of s. 2 6A  of the Indian Income Tax Act

anchor.surface_text: s. 2 6A  of the Indian Income Tax Act. anchor.surface_text: s. 2 6A  was an inclusive and not an exhaustive definition, and even if the distribution of the right to the shares of the Bank of India could not be regarded as dividend within the extended meaning of that expression in s. 2 6A , it was still dividend within the ordinary meaning

anchor.surface_text: But by the form of the resolution sanctioning the distribution, the true character of the resolution could not be altered. We are therefore of the view that the High Court was right in holding that the distribution of the right to apply for and obtain two shares of the Bank of India at half their market value for each share held by the shareholders of the Mills amounted to distribution of dividend.

arguments.claim: s.2(6A) defines dividend inclusively, adding to ordinary meaning which is distributive share of profits or income to shareholders

anchor.surface_text: Dividend is defined in s. 2 6A  as inclusive of various items and exclusive of certain others which it is not necessary to set out for the purpose of this appeal. Dividend in its ordinary meaning is a distributive share of the profits or income of a company given to its shareholders.

arguments.claim: Tribunal question on whether distribution is dividend within s.2(6A) requires High Court to consider both normal and extended meanings

anchor.surface_text: By the definition in s. 2 6A , dividend means dividend as normally understood and includes in its connotation several other receipts set out in the definition. The Tribunal had referred the question whether the distribution of the right to apply for the Bank of India shares amounted to distribution of dividend within the meaning of s. 2 6A  and in answering that question, the High Court had to take into account both the normal and the extended meaning of that expression.

arguments.claim: Dividend need not be money; may be distributed by delivery of property or right having monetary value

anchor.surface_text: Dividend need not be distributed in money it may be distributed by delivery of property or right having monetary value. The resolution, it is true, did not purport to distribute the right amongst the shareholders as dividend.

arguments.claim: The form of the resolution does not alter the true character of the transaction as distribution of dividend

anchor.surface_text: But by the form of the resolution sanctioning the distribution, the true character of the resolution could not be altered. We are therefore of the view that the High Court was right in holding that the distribution of the right to apply for and obtain two shares of the Bank of India  at half their market value  for each share held by the shareholders of the Mills amounted to distribution of dividend.

arguments.claim: Mills' request to allot shares to nominees amounted to transfer of the right, distributing value of Rs.200 per share held by shareholders

anchor.surface_text: The Mills requested the Bank of India to allot the shares to its nominees, and the request for allotment to its nominees amounted to transfer of the right. By its resolution, the Mills in truth transferred a right of the value of Rs. 200 for each share held by its shareholders.

arguments.claim: If Mills sold the right and distributed proceeds, it would be dividend; direct transfer achieves same benefit

anchor.surface_text: It was open to the Mills to sell the right to the shares of the Bank of India in the market, and to distribute the proceeds among the shareholders. Such a distribution would undoubtedly have been distribution of dividend. If instead of selling the right in the market and then distributing the proceeds, the Mills directly transferred the right, the benefit in the hands of the shareholders was still dividend.

holdings.text: the distribution of the right to apply for and obtain two shares of the Bank of India at half their market value for each share held by the shareholders of the Mills amounted to distribution of dividend

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the view that the High Court was right in holding that the distribution of the right to apply for and obtain two shares of the Bank of India  at half their market value  for each share held by the shareholders of the Mills amounted to distribution of dividend.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Valuable right transferred proportionally to shareholders equivalent to profit distribution; dividend includes non-monetary benefits; substance determines character not form; analogous to selling right and distributing proceeds
